questions.text: A 65-year-old woman presents with diarrhoea. She had a past history of radiotherapy for ovarian cancer. Small intestine biopsy reveals villous atrophy, crypt hypertrophy, chronic inflammatory cell infiltrate of lamina propri, and increase in intraepithelial lymphocytes. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The findings of small bowel biopsy indicate celiac disease.

  • Also known as celiac sprue or gluten-sensitive enteropathy.
  • Occurs due to an immune response to gluten (wheat, rye, barley)ingestion and is characterized by autoantibodies to tissue transglutaminase.

Radiation enteropathy (Option A): Although the patient has a history of radiotherapy, radiation enteritis typically shows mucosal ulceration, fibrosis, and vascular sclerosis - not classic villous atrophy with intraepithelial lymphocytosis and crypt hyperplasia.

Ischaemic colitis (Option C): Usually affects the large intestine, not the small bowel. Histology typically shows mucosal necrosis and submucosal hemorrhage - not villous atrophy.

Crohn's disease (Option D): Can involve the small bowel but shows transmural inflammation, granulomas, and skip lesions. The biopsy pattern here - villous atrophy and increased intraepithelial lymphocytes - is not typical of Crohn's.

questions.text:
A 62 lady has symptoms of intermittent abdominal pain and loose stool which have occurred over 1 year.
Investigations reveal:
Hb 8.5 g/dl
MCV 85 fl
WCC 6 x 10^9/l
Iron 11 (14-29) μmol/l
Ferritin 20 (15-200) μmol/l
Folate 2 (3-20) microg/l
What investigation should be done?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The combined iron and folate deficiency anaemia, as well as symptoms suggestive of malabsorption, makeceliac disease a likely diagnosis.

  • Suspected in: Patients with iron + folate deficiency anemia and malabsorption symptoms.
  • Affected areas: Proximal small bowel - duodenum and jejunum.
  • Biopsy findings:
    • Villous blunting
    • Crypt hyperplasia
    • Increased intraepithelial lymphocytes
  • Initial screening (serology):
    • Anti-tTG IgA (tissue transglutaminase IgA)
    • Anti-endomysial antibody (EMA)
    • Deamidated gliadin peptide (DGP) antibodies
    • Total IgA (to rule out IgA deficiency causing false negatives)
  • Follow-up: Small bowel biopsy if serology is positive.
  • Genetic markers: HLA-DQ2 and HLA-DQ8
    • High negative predictive value (useful if patient stopped gluten before testing)
    • Not diagnostic (many carriers don't develop disease)

Ultrasound of abdomen (A):

Not helpful in assessing mucosal diseases like celiac. It may miss early or subtle findings of malabsorption.

Smooth muscle antibodies (C):

Associated with autoimmune hepatitis, not malabsorption or nutritional deficiencies.

ERCP (D):

Used for biliary and pancreatic ductal pathologies. No indication of cholestatic pattern or biliary obstruction here.

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman has previously had a right hemicolectomy and resection of 30 cms of terminal ileum for ileocaecal Crohn's disease. She has persistent diarrhoea, which is not explosive. She does not have abdominal pain, bloating, or loss of weight. Investigations have failed to demonstrate evidence of recurrent Crohn's disease. Which is the best therapy for the symptoms?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The patient has had resection of the terminal ileum and the cause of the diarrhoea is likely to be due to Bile Acid Malabsorption (BAM). This causes a secretory diarrhoeathat worsens with eating.

Role of Bile Acids

  • Primary bile acids: Cholic acid & Chenodeoxycholic acid
  • Conjugated in liver: With taurine and glycine
  • Function: Facilitate fat and lipid absorption in the small intestine

Enterohepatic Circulation

  • After aiding lipid absorption, bile acids are reabsorbed in the terminal ileum and recycled
  • Disruption at any step can cause bile salt deficiency and malabsorption

Diseases Affecting Bile Acid Recycling

Terminal Ileum Involvement < 100 cm

  • Bile acids spill into the colon
  • Stimulates water secretion → Bile Acid Diarrhoea
  • No steatorrhoea (fat is still absorbed)
  • Responds well to bile acid binding agents (e.g., Cholestyramine)

Extensive Ileal Disease > 100 cm

  • Significant loss of bile acids → inadequate fat absorption
  • Causes Fatty Acid Diarrhoea
    • Steatorrhoea present (due to fat malabsorption)
    • Does NOT respond to bile acid binders like cholestyramine

Examples of conditions that causes bile acid loss

Prednisolone (A):Steroids are used for active inflammatory flares in Crohn's disease. This patient shows no signs of recurrence or inflammation.

Mesalazine (B):Primarily used in ulcerative colitis; limited efficacy in Crohn's, especially for non-inflammatory symptoms like bile acid diarrhoea.

Azathioprine (C):Immunosuppressant for maintenance of remission in IBD. Not useful in managing diarrhoea due to bile acid malabsorption.

questions.text:
A 63-year-old male presents with a two-month history of shortness of breath, weight loss, and lethargy. He looks pale and is jaundiced.
Investigations show :
Haemoglobin 6 g/dL
MCV 106 fL
White cell count 2.2 x 10^9/L
Platelets 60 x 10^9/L
Urinalysis: Increased urobilinogen.
What is the next appropriate test?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This patient has pancytopenia with high MCV and an increased urinary urobilinogen, which is suggestive of an unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, indicating a haemolytic process.
  • A high MCV is seen in most of the haemolytic anemias, as the reticulocytes are larger in size than mature RBCs.
  • There are several diseases which can cause haemolytic anemia with pancytopenia. The mechanism may be different.
  • E.g.: SLE, Lymphomas, etc, where the mechanism is immune-mediated mediated
  • PNH, where it is due to associated bone marrow hypoplasia.
  • Vitamin B12 deficiency, where there will be inadequate nuclear maturation of all the cell lines.
  • So the patient mentioned above can have any of these. The basic distinction between these can be made with a Coomb's Test.
  • If it comes as positive patient can be worked up for diseases like SLE or Lymphoma.
  • If it is negative, the patient can be investigated for PNH or B12 deficiency.
  • So the first step in any haemolytic anemia is a Coombs' test.


Colonoscopy (B):Not indicated as first-line in evaluating pancytopenia or haemolysis. It's used for GI malignancy screening, not anemia with unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia and high MCV.

Vitamin B12 concentration (C):Though B12 deficiency can cause pancytopenia with high MCV, it does not explain the jaundice and increased urobilinogen, which points towards hemolysis. Coombs' test is needed first to confirm or exclude immune-mediated hemolysis.

Bone marrow aspirate (D):Invasive and not a first step. Reserved for unclear pancytopenia after basic workup, including hemolysis studies.

questions.text:
A 63-year-old man complains of a 6-month history of lethargy, fever, weight loss, arthralgia, and diarrhoea. Jejunal biopsy reveals flattened mucosa with evidence of periodic acid Schiff (PAS) positive macrophages.
What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The presence of PAS-positive inclusions in the macrophages in a patient with chronic malnutrition, with arthralgia and fever may be either Tuberculosis or Whipple's Disease. Both of them cause PAS-positive macrophages. But Mycobacterium tuberculosis is acid-fast, whereas Tropheryma whipplei is non-acid-fast.Since the question does not mention anything about the acid fastness, we assume it to be negative. Moreover, Tuberculosis mainly affects the ileum; here jejunum is involved.

Hence this is a case of Whipple's disease.

  • It is a chronic, multiorgan disease caused by Tropheryma whipplei - gram-positive, non-acid-fast bacillus.
  • Most commonly occurs in middle-aged men.
  • Classically presents with arthralgias, weight loss, diarrhea, and abdominal pain.
  • Central nervous system and cardiac involvement are common and occur later in the disease.
  • The intestinallesion is also characterized by PAS-positive macrophages, which fills the lamina propria.

Figure showing H and E staining of the jejunum, where the lamina propria is replaced by foamy macrophages. The PAS staining will be positive in the macrophages as shown below:

Treatment is with a prolonged course of antibiotics; optimal regimen is uncertain.

  • Penicillin + streptomycin for 2 weeks, followed by 1 year of trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole.

Tuberculosis (A):

Though TB can show PAS-positive macrophages, the organism is acid-fast, which distinguishes it from Tropheryma whipplei. Also, TB typically affects the ileum, not the jejunum.

Tropical sprue (B):

Presents with malabsorption and megaloblastic anemia, but biopsy would show villous blunting without PAS-positive macrophages.

Helminthic infection (D):

Helminths cause eosinophilia and GI symptoms but not PAS-positive macrophages. Jejunal biopsy would more likely show inflammatory infiltrates or parasite structures.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man has abdominal pains, weight loss, and diarrhoea. He was subsequently found to be lactose intoleran,t and a small bowel biopsy showed changes consistent with celiac disease. He has also noticed that he is developing itchiness and a generalised rash.Which one of the following skin conditions is it likely to be?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Dermatitis herpetiformis is the most common extraintestinal manifestation of celiac disease.

  • It presents as an intense pruritic rashconsisting of papules and vesicles.
  • Commonly presents on the extensor surfaceof extremities, buttocks, and neck.
  • Occurs due to granular IgA depositsin epidermal basement membrane.
  • Treatment - Dapsone and gluten-free diet.

Erythema marginatum (A):This is associated with rheumatic fever, not celiac disease. It presents as transient, non-itchy, serpiginous rash mainly on the trunk and proximal limbs.

Erythema chronicum migrans (C):Characteristic of Lyme disease, it appears as a slowly expanding annular lesion at the tick bite site. Not related to celiac disease or GI symptoms.

Pityriasis rosea (D):Typically begins with a herald patch, followed by a Christmas tree pattern rash. It's self-limiting and not associated with gluten sensitivity or celiac disease.

questions.text: A 64-year-old man has symptoms of lethargy and vomiting. He drinks 10 pints of beer a day. He was started on an intravenous glucose infusion and chlordiazepoxide. For a day, he symptomatically improved. However, the next day, he became confused and started vomiting several times. He also had diplopia and was unable to stand. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This is a case of Wernicke's encephalopathy. It is a neurological disorder of ;acute onsetcaused by a thiamine (B1) deficiency.
  • People who are at risk for acute thiamine deficiency are:
    • Alcoholism, chronic diuretic use, bariatric surgery, hyperemesis, thiaminases in food
  • Symptoms include:
    • Ocular abnormalities(horizontal nystagmus, ophthalmoplegia)
    • Ataxia
    • Confusion.
  • The episode may be precipitated by intravenous dextrose administration, which exhausts vitamin B reserves, especially in alcoholics and malnourished .Supplementation with vitamin B should be done in all alcoholic patients before dextrose administration.
  • Treatment is 200mg thiamine 3 times daily until there is no further improvement, followed by oral thiamine till complete recovery.
  • Cardiovascular and ophthalmoplegia recover in 24 hours. Psychosis may be permanent or persist for months.

Delirium tremens (Option A): Typically presents with agitation, hallucinations, tremors, tachycardia, and hypertension. This patient's presentation includes ataxia and ophthalmoplegia-more in line with Wernicke's encephalopathy.

Hepatic encephalopathy (Option B): Usually seen in the context of decompensated liver disease. It presents with flapping tremor (asterixis), altered mental status, and elevated ammonia-not classic ophthalmoplegia or ataxia.

Cerebellar stroke (Option C): May cause ataxia and vertigo but does not explain the ophthalmoplegia and confusion. Also, the sudden worsening after glucose administration favors a metabolic cause, not vascular.

choices.text: Broad spectrum antibiotics with folate supplementation

questions.text: A 30-year-old male who was staying in Cuba for the past year, now comes with a history of chronic diarrhoea, weight loss, and multiple nutritional deficiencies. He had tried stopping wheat and barley in his diet, but with no improvement in symptoms. A small bowel biopsy showed villous blunting with dense mononuclear infiltrate. The tissue transglutaminase antibody is negative. What will be the next best step?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The history of malabsorption with a recent stay in Cuba points to the diagnosis of Tropical sprue.

However, it could also be refractory celiac disease, where the patient stops responding to gluten restriction, has a negative antibody screen, and has active histopathological findings. In such cases, an HLA DQ testing should be the next best step. But here, since history states that he is coming from a country in the tropics, a course of antibiotics and folate supplementation will be the next best cost cost-effective step.

  • Tropical sprue is considered to be post post-infectious complication.
  • It is seen in countries like Southern India, Philippines, Puerto Rico, Pakistan, and Cuba.
  • It is characterized by severe malabsorption and two or more unrelated nutritional deficiencies including Vitamin B12 and Folic acid.
  • The histopathology is very much similar to Celiac disease, but there will be more dense mononuclear infiltrate, and they will have a negative antibody screen and will not respond to gluten restriction.
  • The management isa prolonged course of tetracyclines with folate supplementation, since folate malabsorption is prominent

HLA DQ testing (Option B):Useful in refractory celiac disease to rule out HLA-DQ2/DQ8 negativity (which effectively excludes celiac). However, this patient is from Cuba, a tropical region, and the clinical picture fits tropical sprue, not celiac disease. Thus, empirical treatment is more appropriate and cost-effective initially.

Oral prednisolone (Option C):Steroids may be considered in refractory celiac or certain autoimmune enteropathies, but are not first-line for tropical sprue. Starting immunosuppression without ruling out an infectious/treatable cause would be inappropriate.

Cholestyramine (Option D):Used for bile acid diarrhoea post-terminal ileal resection or mild bile acid malabsorption-not helpful in infective or inflammatory causes of malabsorption like tropical sprue.

questions.text: A 32-year-old psychology lecturer has deranged liver function tests. She also has jaundice, pruritus, and xanthelasmata.B lood tests reveal elevated levels of conjugated bilirubin, alkaline phosphatase, gamma-glutamyl transpeptidase and positive anti-mitochondrial antibody. She seeks advice about the associations of the disease. Which one of the following is likely to be associated?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The diagnosis is primary biliary cirrhosis (PBC).

  • Presents in middle-aged females with chronic fatigue, jaundice, and pruritis (worse in evenings).
  • Hyperpigmentation and xanthelesma are seen due to altered cholesterol metabolism.
  • Associated with autoimmune conditions such as Hashimoto's thyroiditis, celiac disease, and systemic sclerosis. Osteomalacia is seen due to impaired vitamin D absorption.

Investigations:

  • Cholestatic liver pattern (ALP >> AST). Elevated bilirubin, ϒ - glutamyl-transpeptidase.
  • Anti- mitochondrial antibody (AMA) positive
  • Liver biopsy - Inflammation and necrosis of small- and medium-sized bile ducts.
  • IgM is raised.

Treatment:

  • Ursodeoxycholic acid
  • Liver transplantation

Raised IgA (Option A): Associated with alcoholic liver disease and IgA nephropathy, not primary biliary cholangitis (PBC). PBC is characteristically associated with raised IgM.

Hyperparathyroidism (Option C): Not classically associated with PBC. It may contribute to hypercalcemia, but bone disease in PBC is primarily due to vitamin D malabsorption, leading to osteomalacia or osteoporosis, not parathyroid pathology.

Nephrotic syndrome (Option D): Unrelated to PBC. Nephrotic syndrome can cause xanthelasmata due to hyperlipidemia, which may confuse the picture, but it doesn't fit the autoimmune liver disease profile with AMA positivity.

questions.text: A 44-year-old man visits his family doctor with symptoms of flushing and dizziness. He also has watery diarrhoea several times a month. On examinatio,n he has a systolic murmur in the tricuspid area and a parasternal heave over the left sternal edge. A 24-hour urine shows raised 5HT levels. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This is a case of carcinoid syndrome.

  • Occurs due to increased metabolism of tryptophan into serotonin (5 HT).
  • Presents with episodic flushing, diarrhea, wheezing.
  • Right-sided valvular heart disease (eg, tricuspid regurgitation, pulmonic stenosis) can be seen.
  • Niacin deficiency (pellagra). Niacin is derived from tryptophan. In carcinoid syndrome, all the tryptophan is converted to serotonin. This causes a deficiency of niacin.
  • Diagnosed by raised urinary 5-HT levels.

Tropical Sprue (A): Presents with malabsorption, steatorrhea, and vitamin deficiencies-not flushing, murmur, or raised 5HT.

Crohn's Disease (B):Causes chronic GI symptoms and weight loss but lacks flushing, serotonin elevation, or cardiac involvement.

Phaeochromocytoma (C): Causes episodic hypertension, headache, and sweating-not diarrhea, flushing, or elevated serotonin

questions.text: A 63 year woman with a long history of alcohol abuse has been on Phenytoin for epilepsy. On examination, she has a palpable a liver edge. Her full blood count reveals: Hemoglobin 11.0 g/dL MCV 116 fL white blood count 2.3 x 10^9/L platelet count 95 x 10^9/L What is the likely explanation for these results?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This patient presents with a clinical picture consistent with megaloblastic anemia.

Megaloblastic anemia is either due to Folic acid or Vitamin B12 deficiency.

Given her history of heavy alcohol intake and phenytoin usage, folate deficiency is the most likely cause.

Aplastic anaemia (Option A): Causes pancytopenia but typically with normocytic or slightly macrocytic cells. Also less likely to present with a palpable liver edge or be triggered by alcohol/phenytoin specifically.

Vitamin C deficiency (Option B): Causes scurvy, leading to bleeding gums, poor wound healing-not macrocytic anemia or pancytopenia.

Iron deficiency (Option C): Causes microcytic anemia (low MCV), whereas this patient has a high MCV (116 fL).
